legal_regulatory.title: Legal and Regulatory
findings: Legal & Regulatory Malaysia is actively exploring the foundation of its AI legal and regulatory landscape through the development of sector-specific regulations, and mechanisms for AI local content ownership and intellectual property protection.

At the implementation stage, efforts are underway to introduce sector codes of ethics, conduct AI risk and impact assessments, and enforce sector-specific regulations, particularly around cybersecurity and data protection.

As Malaysia moves toward enhancement, the focus is on institutionalizing responsible AI through compliance-driven governance, strengthening cross-agency collaboration, and building public trust in AI systems.
Socio-Cultural In the socio-cultural dimension, Malaysia is currently exploring how to integrate cultural and heritage considerations into AI governance and ethics.
Implementation efforts are visible through initiatives that focus on AI workforce readiness and skill matching to ensure that AI deployment aligns with societal and workforce needs.

Moving into the enhancement stage, the development of AI fundamental and applied curricula, along with certified professional training, marks progress toward embedding socio-cultural relevance and ethical awareness into AI education and practice.

Education & Capacity Building Malaysia’s AI education and capacity building efforts are in the exploratory phase with the identification of AI leaders and champions across sectors and the conceptualization of a systematic support system for talent mobility.

Implementation has progressed through curriculum review processes, targeted upskilling initiatives based on socio-economic needs, and standardization of TVET (Technical and Vocational Education and Training) frameworks to align with AI competencies.
strengths: At the enhancement level, Malaysia is investing in the development of advanced, market-driven AI curricula and expanding the pipeline of certified trainers to ensure the workforce is future-ready.
Technology & Infrastructure While the exploration phase is not explicitly outlined, Malaysia has made notable strides in the implementation of technology and infrastructure initiatives.

At the enhancement stage, efforts are now directed toward establishing robust data governance frameworks to ensure secure, ethical, and efficient data usage in support of scalable and sustainable AI deployment across sectors.
gaps: While this remains a nascent area, it reflects awareness of the need to localize AI principles within Malaysia’s diverse society.
However, there is currently limited progress in implementation and enhancement, indicating a gap in strategic investment mechanisms and ecosystem-wide economic support.
Bridging this gap will be essential to enable Malaysia’s AI-driven economic transformation and ensure that domestic enterprises can thrive in the global AI landscape.

Foreword
The rapid rise of artificial intelligence (AI) holds immense 
promise for advancing societies, yet it also poses profound 
ethical and social challenges. Left ungoverned, AI risks 
deepening inequalities, eroding privacy, and undermining 
the very rights that define our shared humanity. In this 
pivotal moment, UNESCO’s Recommendation on the 
Ethics of Artificial Intelligence unanimously adopted 
by all 193 Member States in 2021 stands as a global 
compass, guiding nations to harness AI’s potential while 
safeguarding human dignity, equity, and sustainability. 
Malaysia has emerged as a regional leader in answering 
this call. Through its steadfast commitment to ethical AI governance, the country exemplifies 
how innovation can coexist with inclusivity. Central to this effort is Malaysia’s proactive 
embrace of UNESCO’s Readiness Assessment Methodology (RAM), a participatory tool that 
empowers nations to diagnose strengths, address gaps, and chart pathways for responsible 
AI. 
RAM goes beyond a prescriptive checklist; it is a country-led consultative process designed 
to identify institutional strengths, regulatory gaps, and policy opportunities. It offers context 
specific, evidence-based guidance across five key dimensions: legal and policy frameworks; 
data and digital infrastructure governance; education and research ecosystems; economic 
and labour market capacity; and societal inclusion and awareness. The RAM process 
in Malaysia reflects a pioneering vision. Over 300 stakeholders from 28 government 
ministries and agencies, 9 higher education institutions, 9 key industries, and 10 relevant 
associations participated in vibrant consultations. Government agencies underscored the 
urgency of strengthening

recommendations.title: WAY FORWARD Malaysia is strategically advancing its position to harness Artificial Intelligence (AI) as a transformative driver of national development.
recommendations.text: WAY FORWARD Malaysia is strategically advancing its position to harness Artificial Intelligence (AI) as a transformative driver of national development. With a clear vision to evolve into a high- income, innovation-driven digital economy, the government has adopted a comprehensive and ethical approach to AI through the National AI Roadmap (AI-RMap) 2021–2025. Aligned with UNESCO’s Recommendation on the Ethics of AI, the roadmap integrates key national strategies including the Malaysia Digital Economy Blueprint, DSTIN 2021–2030, and the 10- 10 MySTIE Framework. Moving forward, the successful implementation of Malaysia’s AI agenda will hinge on reinforcing the principles of Responsible AI, fairness, safety, privacy, inclusiveness, transparency, accountability, and human-centricity as articulated in the National Guidelines on AI Governance and Ethics (AIGE). These voluntary guidelines should evolve into enforceable standards, ensuring ethical AI adoption across sectors. Institutionally, the establishment of the National AI Office (NAIO) in December 2024 provides the governance structure needed to transition Malaysia from an AI user to a competitive AI innovator. NAIO must strengthen coordination among government, industry, academia, and civil society to scale responsible AI solutions nationwide. To achieve this, Malaysia must focus on five critical areas: 1. Regulatory and Ethical Strengthening: Update existing legislation, develop sector-specific policies, and implement robust compliance mechanisms to ensure AI systems align with national values and international ethical standards. 2. Capability Building & Talent Development: Expand digital and AI literacy across the public sector, establish dedicated AI governance roles, and grow localized datasets that reflect Malaysia’s unique social and cultural contexts. With sustained commitment, Malaysia is well-positioned to lead the region in responsible, ethical, and inclusive AI development ensuring that AI serves all Malaysians, equitably and sustainably.
